intro: Cinchona micrantha var. affinis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved quinine tree, is a species native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces red berries that contain seeds, and its bark has historically been a source of quinine, used in the treatment of malaria. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in montane forests at elevations between 1,000 and 2,500 meters.
